ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TRAINING OF NATIONAL SERVICEMEN
(Scarcity of land)


    1. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence, as land grows increasingly scarce in Singapore so that the problem of training a large number of National Servicemen becomes more and more acute, how his Ministry proposes to solve this problem.

    The Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, over the past 10 years, troop training strength of the SAF has increased fourfold, from 35,000 to 135,000. But military training areas in Singapore have steadily shrunk from a total of 206 sq km to 80 sq km today. In particular, the live firing area in Pasir Laba has diminished from 28 sq km to 21 sq km with the construction of the four new reservoirs of Tengeh, Poyan, Murai and Sarimbun.

    The remaining 59 sq km are gazetted as "manoeuvring areas". No live firing is allowed. Only the 14 sq km on Pulau Tekong are exclusively reserved for military training. A large part of the other 45 sq km is used for housing, industry, agriculture, cemeteries and reservoirs.

    Even more training land will have to be released in the next few years. The efficient use of the remaining area is therefore a real challenge. Some of the measures Mindef has taken are:

    (a) Conducting as much preparatory training as possible within SAF camps so that full benefit is derived when the troops are in the training areas. Training simulators have been installed for basic skills training at individual and crew level.

    (b) Installing training facilities which make more intensive use of time and land. An SAF Wargames Centre has been set up to supplement field training for commanders. A Basic Combat Training Centre for reservists will be ready in July 1985, consisting of training stations, each designed to refresh the reservist on a particular combat skill. In this way many

Column: 896

reservists can be trained simultaneously on the same plot of land.

    (c) Reducing the area "sterilized" by rifle ranges. Bullet stoppers known as baffles are being installed in all the ranges. This frees the surrounding land for training and other uses.

    The training areas are crowded with troops from many units sharing the same training grounds. Training during week-ends has become a normal occurrence for national servicemen and reservists alike. In populated areas, troops have to keep to tracks and roads to avoid encroaching on farms and private properties. Inevitably, realism in training is lost.

    It is not possible to raise an army without allocating a minimum acreage for training. Housing, industry, and other economic and social pursuits must leave enough land to assure SAF operational readiness. Overseas training, which the SAF does in countries like Australia, New Zealand, Philippines and Brunei, is not a solution. Whilst friendly countries may accommodate small contingents of SAF forces to practise specialized manoeuvres, no country, however well disposed towards Singapore, can afford to allow us to train our whole army there all the time. Besides, the cost to us of doing so would be exorbitant. Land is scarce in Singapore, but the SAF must always be allocated its fair share of the land.

    Less land will be required for SAF training if the land can be used as intensively as Pasir Laba and Pulau Tekong. The Government has therefore decided to set aside some plots of land exclusively for military training. These will be the training villages mentioned in the Addendum to the President's Address. Troops can manoeuvre freely without trampling on pig farms or orchid plantations. Units can practise their battle drills properly, and be systematically put through their paces. It will be a workable although not an ideal solution to our training problems.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, could the Minister tell the House how much land is needed for these training villages, and where will these villages be?

Column: 897



     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are thinking of about eight training villages under SAF control, totalling 21 sq km. Despite having these training villages, the total amount of land which the SAF would have available will go down. Today we have 80 sq km. By 1988, even with the training villages, we will only have 66 sq km. Where will they be? They will be in places where the land use is compatible, places which have been reserved for long-term development but will be available for the next 10, 20 years, for example, Seletar, West Bukit Timah, and parts of Marsiling and Mandai.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, can the Minister of State state whether land has been set aside by Mindef for other than non-military purposes, for example, growing of fruit trees and vegetables.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: All land set aside by Mindef is for military purposes. Where we have an air base, a certain amount of land around the air base is sterilized because there are ammunition dumps and fuel dumps. These areas have to be set aside for safety reasons and for security reasons. You cannot build tall buildings on these areas, because they would get in the way of our aircraft. But rather than leave the land totally fallow, we plant trees, and if we are going to plant trees, where it is feasible, we plant fruit trees.

SING-THAI FARM
(Supply of pigs)


    2. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the future of the Sing-Thai Farm; (b) whether the supply of pigs will be affected if the farm is closed; and (c) whether alternative sources of supply of pigs from other countries have been secured.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Sing-Thai Farms Co. Ltd was established in 1979 by the Thai Government and the Primary Industries Enterprise (Pte) Ltd to initiate the export of disease-free pigs from Thailand to Singapore. This role has been fulfilled and the farm has been able to show the way for

Column: 898

other pig exporting farms in Thailand to export their pigs to Singapore. The farm has served its purpose. The management of Sing-Thai Farms is now reviewing the role and objective of the farm.

    In 1984, the Sing-Thai Farms exported only 1,100 pigs to Singapore. This number of pigs is insignificant and will not affect the overall supply of pig% in Singapore, even if the farm is closed. The question of securing alternative sources of supply of pigs from other countries to replace those supplied by the Sing-Thai Farms therefore does not arise.

LITIGATIONS OVER MEDICAL INCOMPETENCE
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Finance, Minister for Education and Minister for Health (a) how many doctors have been sued in the past 10 years for negligence or incompetence; (b) how many patients have died as a result of such negligence or incompetence; and (c) whether it is necessary to have a "sue the doctors and hospitals" campaign for the benefit of the general public.

     The Minister for Finance and Minister for Education and Minister for Health (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answers are as follows:

    First, during the past 10 years (from 1975 to 1984) four legal suits were lodged against Government doctors for negligence or incompetence, The Ministry does not have data on malpractice suits taken out against doctors in private practice. Of the four cases lodged against Government doctors, two resulted in the death of patients.

    Sir, the Government is of the view that a "sue the doctors and hospitals" campaign is not necessary. Such a campaign would indeed have undesirable repercussions. The constant threat of litigation will induce doctors to practise what is called "defensive medicine", ie, to subject their patients to wasteful and unnecessary investigations, treatment and medication. Doctors will have to pay high insurance premium to protect themselves against lawsuits. The result will be higher medical bills for the patients.

CRACKER FIRING OFFENCES
(Penalties)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law (a) if he will state the number of persons caught letting off fire crackers during the Chinese New Year season; (b) how many were fined and what was the fine; (c) in which areas did the cases occur; and (d) whether the Ministry of Home Affairs will consider (i) stiffer measures or penalties to deter the firing of crackers in the Housing and Development Board estates and other densely populated public places; and (ii) amending legislation to impose stiffer deterrent penalties on those selling fireworks or crackers.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs and Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I reply on behalf of my Minister.

    The number of persons arrested by the Police for letting off fire-crackers or other fireworks during the Chinese New Year season was 15. The police also arrested 34 persons for possession of fire-crackers or fireworks.

    So far, seven persons have been charged in court for discharge and possession of fire-crackers or fireworks. They were fined between $100 and $800 each. In addition, five persons were caught for selling fire-crackers or fireworks. One was sentenced to three months imprisonment, two to one month imprisonment each, and another was fined $1,000.

    The majority of the reported cases occurred in HDB estates. Ang Mo Kio recorded the most number of cases with 34 incidents, followed by Clementi with 17, MacPherson 15, Bukit Merah 15, Yishun 14. Bedok North, Toa Payoh, Whampoa, Ghim Moh and Chai Chee had an average of 10 incidents each. The remaining incidents were thinly spread amongst the smaller HDB estates and other locations.

    Police have repeatedly warned the public against firing crackers. During the Chinese New Year period, police patrols were intensified to look out for persons discharging and possessing fire-crackers

Column: 900

and fireworks. Further, all entry points int Singapore, especially at the Causeway, were closely watched by the Police, Immigration and Customs officers to pre vent as well as to detect smuggling of fire crackers and other fireworks.

    The Dangerous Fireworks Act, 1972, already provides for a fine of not exceeding $5,000 or two years imprisonment, or both fine and imprisonment, for all offences under the Act. There is no provision in the Act which specifically makes the sale of fire-crackers or fireworks an offence. Persons caught selling fire-crackers are charged with possession. If the situation requires, we will consider amending the law to include such a provision in the Act.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, since it is apparent that the letting off of fire-crackers is widespread, particularly in all the housing estates, could the Hon. Minister in-charge assure this House that other measures besides police patrols are in hand to inform or educate the public that such behaviour is not only anti-social but will not do well for the country?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Yes, I think the point is taken. And if school children, for example, are caught for firing crackers, the school authority will normally take action to counsel the children about the dangers of firing crackers.

CIVIL DEFENCE SCHEME
(Particulars)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law, since the implementation of the Civil Defence Scheme, (a) how many constituencies have responded and how many volunteers there are; (b) what training courses have been given to the volunteers; (c) whether he will consider improving and strengthening the civil defence units that have been set up in the constituencies; and (d) whether there are sufficient manpower and other resources to ensure that when their services are required there will be this back-up facility.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the Civil

Column: 901

Defence (CD) Scheme was launched in November 1982, a total of 62 Constituencies have joined the Scheme. 23,126 residents have been registered as volunteers.

    CD volunteers depending on the stage of their training can attend different levels of training. Newly recruited CD volunteers attend basic training in fire-fighting, first-aid, rescue and evacuation. Volunteers with leadership potential are selected for advanced training by attending the Volunteer Commanders' Course at the CD Training School, The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) has, thus far, conducted three such courses. In addition, specialized courses to upgrade the knowledge of volunteers on subjects such as advanced first-aid have also been conducted.

    CD volunteers in Constituencies will be organized into Units with a formal command structure. Regular exercises will be conducted to improve their capability and enhance their effectiveness. These Volunteer Units will be supplemented and strengthened with Reservist Units. In each RC Zone, there will be one Volunteer Company working together with and supporting the Reservist Company to carry out CD operations. The reservists will come from ex-SAF and ex-Police officers. Because of their training in the SAF and Police, these reservists will bring with them experience in dealing with emergency situations. In addition, specialized CD Units trained to undertake complex CD tasks using specialized equipment and heavy plants will be formed to strengthen our CD capability at the Constituencies. The SCDF will continually upgrade the skills of volunteers and reservists through frequent training and exercises to keep them prepared for any emergency.

    The SCDF has drawn up an overall build-up plan to establish CD Units in all Constituencies. The manpower and resources required have also been worked out. When the Force is fully built up, there should be 65,000 reservists and 30,000 volunteers. The reservists would come from ex-SAF, ex-Police and CD reservists. These sources

Column: 902

are adequate for the full build-up of the Force. The equipment for the Units to carry out their missions in an emergency are being purchased in stages as the Units are established. Some of the equipment like heavy plant and transport vehicles will not be purchased. Instead, they will be mobilized from the civil resources. The SCDF will constantly review its manpower and resources to ensure that they are adequate to meet any situation.

NEIGHBOURHOOD POLICE POSTS


    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law (a) whether he will state how many Neighbourhood Police Posts have been set up and in which estates; (b) whether the implementation of the NPP scheme is on schedule; (c) what are the shortcomings encountered, if any; and (d) what plans are in hand to ensure the full cooperation of the residents participating in the scheme.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, 20 Neighbourhood Police Posts (NPPs) have been set up in Toa Payoh, Paya Lebar and Jurong Police Divisions. The main public housing estates covered by these NPPs in the Toa Payoh Police Division are Toa Payoh, Sin Ming, Potong Pasir and Upper Aljunied. The NPPs in the Paya Lebar Police Division are all located in the Ang Mo Kio housing estate. The remaining five NPPs, which are in Jurong Police Division, cover the Jurong East, Jurong West, Boon Lay and Marsiling housing estates.

    The implementation programme has been brought forward by two years. The original programme was to have a total of 91 NPPs to cover the whole island by 1991. The revised plan is to set up the 91 NPPs by 1989 at the rate of 14-15 NPPs every year. This decision follows evaluations by my Ministry as well as by Japanese experts of the NPP system in Toa Payoh Police Division in June 1984 which concluded that the Toa Payoh NPP System was an overwhelming success. The Japanese experts accordingly recommended that the implementation programme should be brought forward by two years.

Column: 903



    While there are no major shortcomings, there have been minor teething problems. A Steering Committee comprising senior police officers closely monitors the implementation of the system. The concept has been well accepted by the community. The NPP System has built up close police-public rapport. In the Toa Payoh Police Division, this close rapport is evident from, among other things, a 45% increase in the number of police reports. This compares with a moderate increase of 14% for the nation as a whole. The public is now more willing to come forward and make reports resulting in the Police apprehending more criminals. Between June 1983 and May 1984, there were 2,839 arrests in the Toa Payoh Police Division as against 1,599 and 1,252 arrests in the two years preceding it.

    Public acceptance of the NPP Scheme is important and efforts are made to obtain the residents' cooperation through wide publicity and explanations about the scheme. Booklets explaining the NPP concept are distributed to the residents. It includes profiles of NPP officers serving the community so that residents can get acquainted with them. NPP officers visit the residents twice a year and this has helped in ensuring understanding of, and support from, the residents.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Hon. Minister of State for Home Affairs and Community Development enlighten this House as to whether the crime situation has somewhat improved since the introduction of the NPP into the housing estates or areas as mentioned by him in his reply?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, since the implementation of the NPP system in the Toa Payoh Police Division, ie 'B' Division, we note that there is an improvement in the crime position in the Division. Compared with the nation-wide figure of a 7% increase, the Toa Payoh Police Division had only a 5.5% increase. And in percentage terms, this is about 20% less than the nation-wide figure.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights)( In Mandarin): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State a question. Since the implementation of the programme has

Column: 904

been brought forward, will the authorities face a shortage of manpower?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: There is no shortage of manpower. We have adequate Police manpower to cope with the programme. When I explained that we will build up the NPP System by 1989, it will be done over a period of time - 14 NPPs a year. So we are able to phase in the manpower required.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. Minister of State has mentioned that the Paya Lebar Police Station covers ---

     Mr Speaker: What is your supplementary question, Mr Heng?

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: I will come to the supplementary question.

     Mr Speaker: Let me have your supplementary question.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Is the Minister of State aware that the whole of Ang Mo Kio is not covered by NPP? There are two parts of Ang Mo Kio - one part in my constituency, Jalan Kayu, there are 26 blocks, and another part in Nee Soon Constituency - which are not covered by NPPs?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Firstly, Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not true that the whole of Ang Mo Kio is not covered. I mentioned earlier on that Ang Mo Kio is covered. We had a scheme extended to Ang Mo Kio in 1984. If the Member is asking whether we are going to have NPPs in his constituency, if he could just wait a little longer, the NPP will be set up.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister of State to go and check properly. I believe that the NPP coverage is on a constituency basis and not on a town basis. So the 26 blocks in Ang Mo Kio that is bounded by Cheng San as well as Chong Boon are not covered by NPPs.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: This is a question of detail, Mr Speaker, Sir. When I mentioned that there are NPPs in Ang Mo Kio, I meant Ang Mo Kio Estate. If the Member is asking me whether we have NPPs in Chong Boon, Kebun Baru and Cheng San, including his constituency, these are details as to the

Column: 905

build-up of NPPs in these constituencies, and I should be glad to let the Member have the details.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

11.24 am

    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [8th March, 1985] (2nd Allotted Day),

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1985 to 31st March, 1986.". [Minister for Finance, Minister for Education and Minister for Health).

     Mr Speaker: Since I have allowed two days for the debate on the Budget Statement, I have decided that at 3.30 pm the Minister for Finance should be given a full hour to wind up the debate. This is only fair enough.

    Question again proposed.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon) (in Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday in Parliament, the Member for Khe Bong said that he had at first wanted to talk about road tax and the increase in diesel tax and taxi fares but since other Members have raised these matters, he did not want to talk about them. But I look at it differently. I feel that any important issue should be repeatedly brought up, so that the more people talk about it and giving more opinions, the more helpful it would be to the formulation of policies and measures. Moreover, these are matters which the people of Singapore are concerned about. Therefore, as representatives of the people, we must try our best to make use of every opportunity to talk about matters that concern the people.

    While the reduction in certain taxes and levies, such as payroll tax, SDF levy and the like, are giving great relief and confidence to the business community, the increases in road tax, petrol tax and taxi fares have brought great burden to the general public. As some Members have mentioned, this would in turn bring about a chain reaction in a rising cost of living and higher prices in consumer goods and services. So this double-sided measure in both increasing and reducing taxes gives people the impression that the Govern-

Column: 906

ment is just taking from one hand and giving it to the other. In Chinese colloquial, it is scooping out a piece of flesh to patch a wound, like you have some wound on the left arm and you try to scoop out a piece of flesh from your right arm to mend the hole in the left arm. So this is actually not a practical way to solve the problem. I wonder whether the Minister for Finance i? applying the same kind of medication.

    The increase in road tax and petrol tax, I think is for the purposes of controlling the number of vehicles on the road and make the use of taxis more efficient. But I feel that the rates should not be so high and it could have been implemented over a period of years in gradual stages of small increases each time. If, all of a sudden, you increase the tax to a great extent, it would appear that you have not taken note of the situation all along and only until now, at the last minute, do you try to increase the tax all of a sudden, overnight. Or, you might have noted the situation but was unable to come to an early decision. I think this is not what an efficient government should do. I hope in future there would not be such a large scale increase of taxes, by 100% or 50%, particularly in the areas of income tax, price of HDB flats and other major matters. The increase in taxi fares will affect the commuters generally. It will perhaps affect certain people more, such as the old and those in the lower income group, particularly those who have to depend on the taxi as the means of transport for a livelihood. The increase in Road Tax and Petrol Tax will have some effect in reducing the number of vehicles, but after a few years the effect will be forgotten and there will be more and more vehicles on the road. Because in Singapore, owning a vehicle is a status symbol, whether it is a necessity or not. Some people must need a car in their job. The Ministers here cannot go about their business without cars, otherwise they would not be able to function properly. The Member for Bukit Ho Swee of the previous Parliament was perhaps the only one who went about without a car. Just like what the Member for Siglap has mentioned yesterday, the living standard of the people of Singapore has risen. So everybody wants to have a car. Although not everybody can afford a car, but car owners would like to retain

Column: 907

their cars and those who are without cars now aspire to have a car of their own. Car possession has become a status symbol of one's standing in the society and one's wealth and success and symbolizes one's prestige. So, having a luxurious car is better than having an ordinary car; having a big car is better than having a small car; and having a smaller car is better than without any car. It has come to my knowledge that in some well-known elite schools pupils often discuss about whose parents' cars are bigger and more luxurious, and so on and so forth. After school, some pupils would go home and ask their parents to buy a better car because their classmates have bigger and more luxurious cars.

    I would like to give another example. A young lady is being courted by some suitors. One suitor comes on foot, one by bus, another by trishaw, yet another by car. Who has got a better chance? If you come in a nice car, you are likely to stand a better chance, other things being equal. Most people, having got a flat, a spouse and children, would next aim to own a car. With a car, one will be able to take his family for an outing or for shopping. It would also give his children and wife some feeling of status.

    Sir, I do not mean to say that the people of Singapore are rather vain and unrealistic. What I am trying to say is that unless our social value concept has changed, our aim of life is still to own a car, after having obtained other necessities of life. Some people are willing to save for a car at the expense of other things such as food and entertainment. There are many suggestions on how to prevent the number of cars from increasing. But I feel that the best and most important solution is to provide a good and efficient public transport system. Our MRT and bus systems should be able to provide our people with a safe, comfortable, convenient, economical and efficient transport service. Only then you can basically solve the problem of car ownership or the number of cars on the road. I hope bus companies or operators would not at this juncture try to increase bus fares to make money to take advantage of the time when taxi fares and petrol tax have increased. They should

Column: 908

not try to make use of the opportunity to make too much out of the public, but should try to improve and provide a more efficient service to the public.

    The other problem I would like to raise is about the Ministry of Culture. This year's budget does not relate to the Ministry of Culture because this Ministry has been disbanded. People in the cultural circle naturally feel that the Government does not give priority to matters of culture.
